'''Tutu Jones''' (born September 9, 1966) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[soul blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG"/> He has cited both [[Freddie King]] and [[Z. Z. Hill]] as influences on his playing style.<ref name="Harriman">{{cite web|url=http://www.swaves.com/Back_Issues/June98/tutu_jones.htm|title=Tutu Jones|author=Bill Harriman|publisher=Swaves.com|accessdate=October 17, 2012}}</ref> Since 1994, Jones has released five [[album]]s.<ref name="AMG"/>
 
==Life and career==
'''John Jones Jr.''' was born in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], [[United States]], the son of a Dallas based [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] guitarist, Johnny B. Jones.  Through his father's work, Jones was introduced to house guests such as Freddie King, L. C. Clark, Ernie Johnson and [[Little Joe Blue]]. Jones began playing the guitar by the age of five, by which time he had acquired his [[nickname]] of Tutu from his father.<ref name="Texas">{{cite book
| first= Alan
| last= Govenar
| year= 2008
| title= Texas Blues: The Rise of Contemporary Sound
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Texas A&M University Press]] 
| location= [[College Station, Texas]], United States
| isbn= 978-1585446056
| pages= 159/65}}</ref> However, his own career began as a drummer in his adolescence, graduating from backing his uncles Barefoot Miller and L. C. Clark, the latter in 1976,<ref name="Harriman"/> before working with Z. Z. Hill and [[R. L. Burnside]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/tutu-jones-mn0000173111|title=Tutu Jones|author=Jason Ankeny |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 17, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Tutu">{{cite web|url=http://www.tutujones.com/bio.html|title=Tutu Jones Biography|publisher=Tutujones.com|accessdate=October 17, 2012}}</ref>

Meanwhile working on his own guitar playing, by 1989 Jones had moved on to fronting his own bands.<ref name="Texas"/>  This in turn led to him recording his debut album, ''I'm For Real'', on [[JSP Records]] in 1994.<ref name="AMG"/> It was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award|W. C. Handy Award]].<ref name="Harriman"/>  ''Blues Texas Soul'' followed two years later, and ''Staying Power'' in 1998.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Tutu"/> 

A [[live album]], ''Tutu Jones Live'', was issued in 2005 by Doc Blues Records. A [[music journalism|journalist]] at ''[[The Austin  Chronicle]]'' then stated, "bluesmen are traditionalists, but Jones learns how to mesh soulful wails with syrupy blues that are as sweaty live as they are in quiet studios."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.docbluesrecords.com/artists_tutu_jones.html|title=Tutu Jones|publisher=Docbluesrecords.com|accessdate=October 17, 2012}}</ref>

His latest album, ''Inside Out'' was released via [[CD Baby]] in 2009.<ref name="Tutu"/>
